text: Surly performed some brewing wizardry with this Mild Ale. Its appearance is a coppery brown - tight one-finger head thanks to the nitro variant I tried. Mellow malty sweet aroma. Caramel, chocolate, nut, and cream flavors. Very little bitterness. Rich feel. Thats where the wizardry comes in. Its the damnedest thing to describe a Mild Ale at 3.8% as rich, but it is.

Nitro tap. Chestnut with a beige head, and aromatics of caramel confectionery. Fairly full for a light bodied beer, but it is thin and has a mineral palate. Very mild roast and caramel flavor that overall is pretty good, but Ive had better milds.

Tap; pours cola brown with a khaki head; aroma of chocolate, nuts, and some floral hints; taste is light sweet with chocolate, nuts, and a hint of caramel; finish is dry with just a touch of bitterness
On tap at Omaha Taphouse 2017 Beer Week. Mostly clear brown color with creamy whitish tan head. Malty, cocoa, sweet aromas. Sweet malty, creamy, slight roasty flavors. Nice and very drinkable mild.
C-. Pours a black color with khaki head. Really smooth, but not a while lot of flavor.

Minnesota Trip Beer #22. Nitro keg at Surly, 5/8/16. Hazy dark red, large creamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of chocolate and nuts. The taste is caramel, chocolate, nuts. Medium bodied, low carbonation, highly drinkable.
An outstanding dark mild that I tried at the Blatt on nitro. Smooth with a dense malty sweetness.
On nitro at HopCat in Lincoln. Pours a brown color with creamy whitish tan head. Malty, cocoa, sweet aromas. Sweet malty, creamy, slight roasty flavors. Top notch mild

Draft (nitro). Pours dark brown with light tan head and substantial lacing. Toast and light chocolate malt aroma. Chocolate and malt up front followed by coffee and more malt. Lighter mouthfeel than expected; more substantial body would be better. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On nitro at surly pours dark brown with huge creamy khaki head. Aroma is dry and earthy saw dust, light toast, caramel, light cacoa, and hop. Light flavors, toasted bread, dry caramel, light milky chocolate, and a dry hop presence. Light and drinkable, nice lively carbonation with the nitro.

Pours a dark golden copper color with bright mahogany edges and a two finger off-white head that slowly settles into a thick, lasting cap. Great retention, taking a while to settle with large streaks of soapy lacing clinging to the glass on the way dow.

Somewhat mild aroma with chocolate malt sweetness and a very faint floral hop presence. Earthy, soily hops followed by light toast, caramel and toffee. Not much else happening. True to style but not very exciting.

Light body thats pretty watered down with faint earthy/grassy hop character countered by slightly toasted light malt sweetness. Grass, pine needle and faint resins followed by caramel, toffee and chocolate sweetness. Somewhat true to style but kind of one dimensional and boring. Hops could be stronger for an American interpretation and the mouthfeel and malts presence could be more interesting for a British version, especially on cask. Unfortunately, this is caught somewhere in between. Not bad, but I wouldnt order this again.
Draft at Bricks. Pours cloudy brown with no head. Nose and taste are mild caramel, toast and chocolate.

Draft. Brown in colour with moderate carbonation. Aromas are of nougat, toasted nuts, and cocoa powder. Flavors are of pale malt, malted chocolate candies, and a bit of orchard fruit notes from the yeast. Slick bodied. Serviceable, but could have used more hop flavor.
On tap at Surly. Not bad for a low ABV brown ale but least favorite I tried at the brew house
Deep red mahogany, light tan head. Corn, light grains on the nose. A bit like Crispex. Sweetish, a touch of bitterness. Quite light, but fairly chewy. Medium finish. Pretty good.

Tap at Surly. Light chocolate nose. Dark translucent brown color, thin tan head, great lacing. Light chocolate initial, very pleasant, toasty sweetness. Basically just thin choco throughout the palate, without much development. Okay. Smooth and moderate all the way. "Mild" is an understatement
DRAFT at Farmhouse in Chicago. Pours dark brown with moderate head. Nose is caramel and a bit of hops. Very mild taste...more chocolate and caramel...goes down way too easy. Tasty but mild.

Definitely an English style ale. Not what i expected from Surly. Mild as described.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured on tap at Emporium. Interesting choice of style - replicating a true British session ale style. Pure malt based brown/caramel hued ale. Some english toffee notes, with minimally noticed aroma. Medium-light mouthfeel, absolutely a beer to take down midweek.
Light brown pour from draft at Clark's. Tons of off white foamy head. Nutty choclate taste. Roasty almonds. Light but good flavor for the low ABV
Malty aroma full of caramel. Red pour with a thin head. Full, smooth mouth feel. Taste is light with roast and caramel. Bitter finish. Very drinkable.
Very little aroma, maybe a little malt. Leaves your mouth with a slight lemon tartness in the aftertaste. Notes of bitter chocolate and coffee.

On Draught at El Bait Shop, multiple times.
Pours a nice brownish red with a small head and lots of lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is nutty & earthy in a nice mossy, woodsy, rich soil... kind of way. The roastiness is light but very well integrated. The beer is aromatic & inviting in every way. 

The flavor is very nutty & rich. Its lightly sweet but satisfyingly bitter. The roastiness is mild but ever-present. Everything is well balanced & well rounded. 

Very enjoyable beer, sessionable, but at the same time very flavorful & not thin or watery in any way. 
Right up my alley.

[Tap] Tried a pint of this at a recent Surly tap takeover. Pours an even brown color with a nice looking head. Aroma consists of cocoa powder, toasted grains and some caramel. Taste of toasted breads, caramel, hazelnut and earthy hops. Good lacing. Nice mouthfeel for the style. Well done!
Milds, like the cream ale are generally boring, this one is not good amounts of bready malty goodness lightly toasted, smooth finish and nice deep color. Solid.

On tap and shaker served at Warrens Ale House in Wheaton, IL., showing a clear & bright, walnut hue, with frothy & persistent, tan head foam, and clingy waves & spots of lacing. The nose was toasted, with a touch of roastiness, nuttiness, caramel, & toffee. Light to medium bodied, with lively carbonation, the taste continued the aroma notes plus mellow malt and low to moderate earthy & roasty bitterness. The nose outshined the taste, but altogether was a sessionable, clean, & crisp, light Brown Ale, that also paired well with the quesadilla appetizers.

Tap - small foamy head, nice medium amber color, sweet malty/bready aroma and flavor, some nutty notes, fair hop balance, smooth drinking - pretty good for a mild

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft, it starts very grainy and toasty, more carbonation tthan expected. As it warms it gets more coffee-like notes. Its decent.

Had it on tap at Northdown. Pours a beautiful deep clear copper color with a beige head. The bark us worse than its bite as far as aroma vs taste. Strong coffee malty alcoholy aroma with a very smooth and mild taste. Things to make you go hmmm.
On tap at paramount room. Poured dark red with min ring of head. Aroma of malt. Light carb med bod. Sweet light roast malt.
Malty amber pour with a slight head. Slight malty nose. Some slight lacing as well as I enjoy the beer. Toast, just a touch of hops and slight bitterness on the finish. Sessionable for sure.

on tap, has a nice dark brown color with a pillowy off white head. Aroma is strong with nuts with and chocolate malt. Taste is very nutty and smooth with hints of coffee and chocolate. very well crafted session beer.

Clear amber color, small off-white head. Papery, grassy, caramelly aroma. Light-bodied, even watery. Nice leafy rustic flavor with some caramel.

Draught @ CBC 2013 [ Yellow Session ]. - Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2013, Sparta Hallen, Gunnar Nu Hansens Plads 11, 2100 Copenhagen, DenmarkClear medium to dark orange amber colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, nutty, earthy, moderate hoppy, cacao - chocolate notes ! Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, fruity, nutty, earthy, light caramel - sweet carmel - toffee, cacao - dusty chocolate notes ! Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20130503]

On tap @ Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2013. This is a clear deep chestnut brown one with a small light bubbly off-white top. It smells of wort and chestnuts ironically enough. Light sweet, something lightly roasted as well. Smells absolutely OK. It has lots of flavor for being a mild one. Not directly sweet, but it has some wort sweetness, lots of nuts and a little bit of chocolate paper. Light dry and woody finish. 03.05.2013

Tap at Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2013 - Session I. Pours clear gold with a fine, white foam head. Light cocoa character, fine bready malts. Light bodied with fine to average carbonation. Lightly toasted malts in the finish, further delicate cocoa. Decent balance. Basic but good.

Sample at CBC 2013.

Clear reddish colour with a small off-white head. Aroma and flavour of caramel, roasted malt, chocolate and fruity notes.

Draft @ Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen. Pours an amber color with a small off-white head. Has a weak roasted malty caramel aroma. Roasted malty spicy caramel flavor. has a roasted malty caramel and chocolate finish.

Tap @ Mikkeller Bar, Cph. Pours clear red with a small, frothy, white film head. Aroma has dusty chocolate, caramel, red apples. Medium carbonation, impressive full mouthfeel. Flavour has more dusty chocolate, caramel, soft apple zest. A bit too dusty and dry for me, but good for the ABV.

3rd May 2013CBC. Bit of tired end of session rating. Light haze on this amber beer, little white head. Light crisp palate. Somewhat insipid malts, Mild minerals. Crisp dry finish. Probably should have had this as the start of the session - its coming over as very wishy washy after all those big beers!

Tap @ CBC 2013. The pours deep amber with a small head. The aromas black tea, chocolate malt. Plums and forest fruits. The taste is more tea. Toasted brown bread. Bruised plum and berry. Light, smooth body. Soft carbonation. Overall, quite good.

From tap. Pours clear and golden orange with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted malty and almost toffee caramelish. Toffee and dry caramelish. Light bitter and mild roasted. Bitter and dry roasted finish.
Draft. An amber beer with a beige head. The aroma has notes of caramel, malt, and fruits. The flavor is sweet with notes of caramel, and malt. The body is light.
Draught at CBC 2013. Clear amber/brown - white head. caramel, tobacco, roasted, grassy, herbal, light sweetness, toasted notes, light hoppy, citrus, orange. OK.
Draught @ CBC. Pours amber with a offwhite head. Aroma of malt, bread, caramel, grassy hops. Flavor is malt, caramel, grassy hops. Thin body, lively carbonation. 030513
Sample @ CBC. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are fruits, caramel, malt and hops.
CBC. Clear amber with a lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and moderate hoppy - grass. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. 030513
Tap @ CBC.Dark amber with small off-white head. Aroma is malt and caramel. Flavour is malt, caramel, toasted, medium sweet and a little bitter.

[5/3/13] Draught at Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2013. Clear amber color. Aroma of malt, a bit of caramel hints and light fruitiness. Flavor has some malt, light fruitiness, dusty touches and a drier finish. Medium-bodied.

Draught @ CBC 2013: Dark amber coloured. Unclear. Dense beige head. Aroma: Light roast, sweetness, some caramel, light toffee. Flavour: Caramel, light roast, some sweetness and chocolate. Medium bodied. Ends light roasted bitter.

Draught at CBC 13. Almost clear copper liquid with medium off-white head. Aroma of pumpernickel, bread, biscuit, pine and toast. Taste is very light sweet and light bitter with notes of pumpernickel, bread and earth. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Nice, really true to style.

Draught at CBC 2013.
Clear orange-red coloured with a medium sized off-white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of hay and grass.
Fruity flavour of hay, grass, chocolate and hops.
Fruity finish.
Draught. Frothy white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Short moderate bitter finish. Oily palate.

On tap at brewery. Pours dark amber brown with a tight off white head that slowly fades to a collar. Aroma is roasted malt veggies and little mild spice and burnt coco. Taste is much the same as above. Palate is medium and finishes chalky. This is not the way I remembered it from last year! Last years was dark brown almost black and hazy with smells of peat chocolate and roasted malt. Something was different!

Draft at the Blue Nile. Pours a clear, light brown color with a tan head and a little lacing. Aroma is bready, toasty, nutty.  Medium on the palate with soft carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, bready, very nutty, some light bitterness, with a nice, fruity malty finish. Great at 4%.
Was hoping this would be one of my go to beers. Didnt happen. Nice color and lacing. Taste is nice and smooth but it just doesnt stand out at all. Least favorite surly.
On tap at Muddywaters in Minneapolis.  Not a fan - tastes too watery with no impact on the ole tastebuds.

On draft during the Surly event at Churchkey in D.C. Review from notes.

The beer is a dark, mahogany brown color with hints of auburn when held to the light. The nose brings caramel malt and roast. Bready and light. This is terrific beer. A fine example of the style, and what a session beer can be. Light bodied and creamy with moderate carbonation. Silky smooth on the palate. I would definitely have this again.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 06-06-2012
Sample on a tour. Pours brown, little aroma. Not a fan of this at first sip, would never buy this. Very bland and boring. Pretty much weak malts with no other distinguishable flavors.

Draft at Churchkey for the Surly event. Beautiful dark brown pour with a frothy head. Nose is reminiscent of a brown porter with english malt, with that beautiful toffee and caramel but with touches of roast complexity and a bit of nice bready texture and light crispness from the hop bill. Awesome bitter finish, with a creamy vanilla-like mouthfeel. Awesome brew for the style, and for the ABV.

On tap at Churchkey during the Surly 10-tap event for Omars visit to DC. Served in a goblet.

Pours a very dark brown, bordering on black. There was a good tan head and some nice lacing on the way down. The nose brought some roasted malt and a bit of coffee. Good integration that gets even better in the flavor. Packed with beautiful malt notes, especially considering the low abv. Light-medium body with a slight bit of chewiness and nice carbonation. Overall, a really excellent beer.

Draft.  Clear garnet-brown body, small beige head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, nut, raisin, some bittersweet chocolate, light smoke.  Taste is moderately sweet, bittersweet chocolate, nut, some raisin, smoke. Light-medium body, light stickiness.

Dark brown pour with hints of garnet and a small white head. Delicious lightly toasted and roasted malts with hints of cocoa nib and creaminess. The flavor holds more amply toasted malt with milk chocolate and bakers chocolate in the finish. Medium body with fluffy carbonation and a chalky finish.
Draft. Dark brown color, small beige head. Aroma of chicolate and roasted coffee beans. Taste is toast and nutella. Nice.
Draft at Churchkey. Clear brown color with a wispy tan head. Aroma was roasted, with nutty notes. Flavor was roasted malts, a bit of toasted nuts, bitter notes. Enjoyable, pretty session-able.

Tap at CK. Clear nut brown pour to darker brown. Smaller tan head. Roasty nose with hazelnut and dark sponge cake. Mild cocoa. Taste is clean, roasty. Almost like the small beer from an imperial stout. Bitter, clean, nutty palate. Nice stuff. Thinner mouthfeel is expected. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

4oz pour at Churchkey.  Pours a transparent dark brown with some creamy off white head.  Nose is roasty and nutty, malty, stale brown bread.  Flavor is malty, bready, sweet, yeasty.  Chalky mouthful.  Sessionable.

Draft at The Happy Gnome. Pours deep cola black, with a thin off-white head, and ropey lacing. Nose is spicy cocoa, with light coffee and gentle hops. Just a wonderfully well-rounded nose. Flavours of root beer, toffee, bright hops, nice smoke, fudge, and coffee. Just beautifully put together, and at 4% I think I might be in love just a little bit!

Date: February 12, 2012 Mode: Draft Source: Republic Description: Semi-opaque dark brown pour with some head.  Roasted malt, chocolate and caramel in aroma and taste.  Finally got my hands on this one after stumbling over from Town Hall with my boy BVery.  "Damn dude I think I left my phone across the street" hahaha.

Amazing scents of chocolate and roasted coffee, the taste was a bit of a let down compared to the aroma. It was a very tame beer when it comes to Surly, but it would probably be my favorite of the style.
Sampled at Winterfest 2012.  true to style and very well done in this respect, but compared to the entire spectrum of beer its just so so.

Sample at the brewery. Dark drown pour with small to medium tan head.  It has caramel and earthy notes on the nose. Nice easy finish. Awesome session ale. Would love to see this in cans. This is a must get when I find it on tap.

Ported from my BA account.

Appearance:
Dark, brown on the edges. If there was any significant head, I missed it (was sitting away from the bar, and they made sure I had a full pint).

Aroma:
Malty, not super sweet, but a nice smell. Roasted barley for sure, and maybe some dryish smelling caramel?

Taste:
Not too sweet, not too dry. a little toasty. No real hops, but very malty.

Mouthfeel: Medium body and heavy.

Drinkability: Good, but I dont know if it should be considered a session beer. I could see myself drinking way more Furious, though Mild would probably be a better decision as far as the ABV goes. A great high-taste, low alcohol sipper for a designated driver.

Serving glass: Poured from tap into pint.

Appearance: Very dark mahogany with thin off-white head.

Aroma: Chocolate, coffee, smoke and caramel.

Taste: Espresso, chocolate, nuts, smoke and caramel. Fairly dry despite the relative lack of hops.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, light body, very dry finish.

Overall: Extremely drinkable and a decent amount of flavor and complexity. Brewers should make more beers like this. Damn you Omar and Todd, can this now!

On tap at brewery, 8 oz sample. Perfect pour resulted in good aroma of light malts and somewhat nutty background. Light lacing, great finish and overall very clean taste. Highly sessionable, look forward to trying this again in the future.
on tap. Deep, poured into a surly pint glass a brown color. smell is kinda nutty and roast coffee. Taste roast with a sweetish finish with some unsweet chocolate with some nuts. ok beer
On tap @ Muddy Pig. Deep brown appearance with a light tan head. Bland dark malty nose. Bitter, dark malty, yet light bodied flavor. Easy drinking session ale.
I like most of Surlys brews.  This however is not a worthwhile ale and pales in comparison to the rest of their line-up.  I wouldve scrapped the batch.

Tap.  Deep, opaque brown in color.  Large nutty aroma, some chocolate, and a bit of roast coffee in the aroma.  Taste is mildly roasty and semi sweet.  Slight cocoa, cream, and what seems like hazelnut appear.  Creamy finish and highly drinkable.  Please can this so!

Firkin at a 5th ani party.  Pours a clear dark brown, only large-ish bubbles for head.  No lacing.  Smell is some roasty malt, a bit of biscuit, some cocco and coffee.  Quite nice.  Flavor is much the same, with pronounced hop bitterness on the end.  Dry finish.  Mouthfeel is not great...firkin doesnt really work with this one.

Draft. Served at Cafe 28 on 1/31/11 by Todd Haug himself for the celebration of 5 years of business. Poured into a snifter a dark brown color with a nice 2 finger tan head, at first I thought I had been given Bender but the aroma soon made me realize I was given the correct beer. The aroma is more pungent than I would have expected with a light roast coffee and chocolate nose. Medium/Light mouthfeel. Very robust flavor with the roast and coffee notes, some mild bitterness as well. Very flavorful and enjoyable. I really wish this was one that they did all year round.

On tap at the Bavarian Lodge, Lisle, IL.

Aroma:Nicely malty and dark.

Appearance:Brown in color, ok head.

Taste:Tons of dark malts, caramel, chocolate, coffee. This tastes hugely malty.

Palate:Medium body, good carbonation.

Overall:Fantastic tasting beer, refreshing and flavorful. As a homebrewer, I find this beer reminiscent of prefermented wort.
UPDATED: SEP 10, 2016 This was not bad but it was really toasted.  It almost smelled a bit like coffee grounds a little too much. Very dark color. Serving: Tap

had about 4 pints of this at firkin in libertyville.  pours a clear dark copper with a medium offwhite head.   aroma of maple syrup, chocolate and coffee.  fresh dough, chocolate, roased nutes.  awesome.  crisp clean.  super refreshing.  want more beers like this.  great stuff.

The epitome of a session ale. Great flavor, decent amount of alcohol, aroma is toasty and keeps you coming back. But mostly this is about the flavor and the mild light body. On tap at Binnys South Loop.

Served in a pint glass at Firkin. Arrived to the bar a dark brown with some garnet highlights and a dense creamy off-white head to top it. Aroma has a strong toasted malt note, reminiscent of cigar leaves, mild grassy hops and a strong biscuit malt ending. Flavor has a very strong cigar leaf-like toasted malt note, very low chocolate malt in the middle that adds a light sweetness, grassy hops in the middle and a biscuit flavor that finishes out the brew. Body is very thin, almost water, with low, fine carbonation that accentuates the mouth feel typically found in the styling. Very nice lacing is left on the glass from this brew as well. Overall a very interesting brew with a very unique tobacco toasted malt flavor. A very solid brew.
Piney hips dominate the aroma. Has a nice large head with a deep amber/red body. Mostly hops come through, buttering quite a bit. Decent, drinkable, but nit something Id choose to session.

On Cask at Night of the Living Ales - had this after the Darkness so my taste buds were probably shot.  Pours light brown - light aroma.  Flavor of biscuit, caramel and some malt.  Mild in flavor alright - but not bad.
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Tap. Clear brown-red pour. All I smell is coffee. Taste is a little flat, with mild caramel and some roastiness. Decent.

Cask version at Night of the Living Ales 2010. Amber brown and a fairly big head for a cask ale (which means slightly more bubbles on top). I really enjoyed this one. Biscuity malt is really full in the nose and just a twinge of roastiness. Pleasantly light in flavor but not at all watery. This style does wonderfully on cask. More carbonation might make this come off as too thin. Finishes w/ a mild bitterness. At least at the festival, this stuff came off as way better than Surly Darkness both for their respective style and in general.

On tap at Stub & Herbs. Poured an amber brown with minimal head. Aroma was full of grain notes with a bit of toast and nuttiness. Flavor was very malty as well with a strong toasted flavor with a hint of chocolate and just a touch of hops.

Pours golden with white head at brewery, aroma is a bit of malt sweetness with bready malt overtones.  Taste is a bit of sweetness up front that leads way into very bready and earthy malt, with little to no bitterness.  The taste is a bit lacking, and it is certainly mild.
Draft.  Brown hazy pour, medium carbonation and standard malt aroma.  Mellow malt flavor/sweetness and finished very nice.  An ok brew, but definitely not my favorite Surly offering.

On tap.  Pours a light clear brown with a with a whitish head.  The nose is subtle, sweet, and pruney.  Definitely dark fruit, not really much or any chocolate.  The mouthfeel is light with lower carbonation than in most draught beers with very little body.  The flavor is in line with the nose.  Lightly sweet, not very creamy, but very figgy with dark fruit and very very light astringency.  A slight hint of roast in the finish, lingering.  Havent had a ton of milds, but I guess this is how I understand them to be.

16 oz draft on tap at Binnys South Loop (Chicago, Il). Pours a nice reddish copper with tannish decent head that sticks around, just a touch hazed. Aromas are a nice biscuity malt, light carmel, and bready with minimal floral aromas. Initial is light and quaffable, carmel and bready malts dance on the palate lightly, with a nice malt body that doesnt get in the way. Moves into a subtle creeping bitterness in the finish with light floral and a nice cereal crispness in the aftertaste. I could drink a lot of this for long periods of time.
Dark amber pour with slight head.  The nose is sweet malted barley.  The flavors are sweet malted barley, bread dough and biscuits.  Very refreshing and drinkable.  Nicely brewed.

Draft at Map Room.I wonder if people that have sampled this understand what a mild is. At any rate, it pours a pale brown with thin head. Nose is malt forward, mild chocolate. Taste is much the same, watery, minimal hop bitterness and a touch grainy. Nice and easy drinking.
[Tap] The beer was flat and tasted like malty water. Where are the hops? Did not get much complexity. Will try a bigger sample next time its available on tap.
small pour at DLD 2K8.  headless light brown clear amber appearance. soapy hops, somewhat watery, lots of malt in aroma, tiny bit of caramel. not a whole ton going on

08 DLD pour.  clear light brown with no head. Flavor had some tea notes,  some hops with a grainy finish.  Thin and watery with no carbonation in the finish.  I think with a bit of bubbles this would have been very refreshing.

Gotta say its very good for the style, which lends itself to low ratings.  Not as sweet as the Comm Desc would have you think, and darker than I expected.  I would give this a slight nod over Pride & Joy, this seemed to have more of a kick.  Either one is a solid bet if you are in session mode.

Winterfest 2008
Little to no head.  The body has a brownish red hue.  Flavor like an amber ale, however, I am going to hopefully rerate this at another time, since this beer was followed by a bunch of monster brews.  Its just hard to compare it when my palate was getting overloaded with the big beers all night.  I actually was going to wait on this and try it at a later date, but when I got to the front of the line, Surly was all out of darkness :(
On tap at Busters, served in a pint glass.  Dark brown body.  Sweet malt aroma.  Flavor more of the same with some roasted malt and cocoa notes. Very drinkable.
On tap at the Muddy Pig in St. Paul.  Dark golden brown in color with a very small white head.  Aroma is overbearing in maltiness.  Malty in flavor as well with no sign of hops (as a mild should be).

On tap at Stub and Herbs.  Pint appeared dark, with a decent head and lots of lace.  The aroma is of bready malt and caramel.  The flavor, sweet, mild, some roasted notes, and a short dryness that hits in the finish.  The palate is pleasant enough.  Nothing wrong with this and very drinkable.  I like it pretty well.
Tap at the nile.  Solid biscuity malt aroma with chocolate hints.  A faint hop in there as well.  Toasted malts with a definite chocolate character and some hops for balance.  Dark brown color.
Tap at Nile.  Pours maroon with a medium tan head.  Nice light malt with very little hop.  Very easy drinking with just enough there to make you want more.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2008 Tap at the Pig.  Very nice biscuity malt and some tropical fruits as well as some light floral hoppy notes.  Nice balanced toasty biscuity sweet malt and tropical fruits fiinish it out.  I am sure this is a killer mild, but having only had one before, and an average one at that I am rating with no tipicity.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Surly Mild release at the Happy Gnome 1/16/08. Malty aroma; a little syrupy. Sweet & sugary. Murky, reddish brown with a thin, tan head. Nice lace. Very little hop. A little vacuous. Malty and dry. Sweetness in nose doesnt translate. Has a nice yeast in the finish. A pleasant, easy drinking session brew that Id order again. The yeast finish makes it.

Semi-clear, reddish brown, with a nice, tight, light tan head.

Mostly malty aroma, caramel & chocolate, toasty, solid. smooth, creamy. Nothing jumps out, but it isnt supposed to.

Taste: Its all about the smooth, and its all about the malt. Hops are here, and higher than other milds, (25 IBUS, if I remember right), and you can just taste them on the tongue, but theyre playing it cool, too. Crisp malt flavor, judiciously applied, lies right underneath every gulp & swallow.
Body is medium light, not anywhere near watery, but surprisingly thin for a Surly brew. Well, this, I guess, is their notice to us, saying, "Watch out, dont categorize us, we can be boring, too!"

I cant help but like Mild, its easy to drink and easy to enjoy, and the malt profile is tasty. Theres just enough flavor to make you happy. And yet, it wasnt designed with my palate in mind, for I keep wanted a bit more...I keep missing the Belgian malts of Bender, or the hop attack of Furious. I got that from my customers, too. Many had a sample and went back to Bender...or Furious. 

Nice low, languid finish, malts hang tight on the tongue and the deliciousness sticks around. 
I take back what I said. This is not a boring beer, just a bit more mellow in flavor than their usual entries. Thats one thing I dont think Surly is capable of: brewing a boring beer. I dont think, like any true artist, Todd has it in him to do so.
Mild does serve a nice niche, though, and I hope to see it again in the future, ...but not at the expense of Furious or bender!

I thought it was like a bitter, and a good one.  Light red in color and very low carbonation.  The aroma is simple malt.  The flavor has abundant malt as well, and has a lightly roasted flavor to it.  Good palate and fairly full bodied for a beer that is in no way complex.  Very drinkable, like a mild or bitter should be.

Tap at the Blue Nile. Only having tried one prior mild ale I wasnt quite sure how to rate this one. I cant really rate to style because the only other mild Ive had was absolutely nothing like this beer. I know... mild ale is a broad and vague category, but I have to echo Nuffields comments that is well more along the lines of a bitter than anything else. Surly has never been known to brew to style anyway. Whatever. 
 Pours a nice looking dark amber/copper with a frothy white head leaving moderate lacing down the glass. Aroma of lightly toasted biscuity malt and subdued grassy hops. Creamy and leaning toward flat on the palate. Almonds, toasted caramel, salt water, spicy rye bread on the tongue. Underwhelming at best.

Pours a deep hazy  brown/red with a thin layer of white head, mostly lacing. Medium bodied. Flavors of caramel and malts followed by a bit of bitterness. Smooth, which is normally the case. Everything seems to be underplayed, from aromas to flavor. Surprised it so subdued. The only thing the beer really has to back it up is that it is by Surly. Expected better. Tapped at Happy Gnome in Saint Paul

On tap at Happy Gnome. Bright brownish red color, some lacing. Medium bodied. Smooth on the palate. Flavor is initially dry nutty malts, followed by a hint of underlying sweetness. Basic dry hop finish. Has that underlying soft Surly quality, but Im not sure what to attribute that to, be it the water or yeast or whatever.  So yes, this beer isnt mind blowing. It shouldnt be. It is, however, a solid session brew. Ironically, Surly came out with a "weaker" beer after coming out with a number of big delicious beers. I say for the style, this is well made.

I was told by the bartender that this is 4.1% abv--not *exactly* mild as I know it (I tend to like it around 3.5, maybe 3.8%)--indeed, if it is 4.1%, it begs the question of how I distinguished this beer from an English bitter.  There are a lot of similarities: theres a strong nut note driving this, but the overall profile is marked by the mildly sweet maltiness producing fruity qualities, esp. raspberry.  The underlying profile, when I could dig it out (served too cold), suggested La Folie.  Yes, thats right, La Folie.  Only, not really because youre dealing here with a very subdued beer that is marked more by its notable carbonation than its elegance of composition.  Deep red/maroon/amber in color.  Basically this seemed more like a bitter on carbonation than the milds I loved most in England.  But then, mild isnt a distinct category.  Only, the best milds I had were essentially lunchtime stouts, rich brown/black with complex chocolates and roastiness.  This brew is forgettable, aided only by the good reputation of this fine brewery.  (on tap, The Happy Gnome)
decent ale, got better as it warmed, thin quickly diminishing head, dark red in color, thin feel in the mouth, long lasting dry ending/aftertaste, aromas were hard to detect

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2012 On tap at the Happy Gnome during the 1/16/08 release.  Dark ruby color with a thin head.  Slight bready aroma.  Nutty taste with a bit of a chalky feel to it.  Very bready.  It tastes like a dark grain bread, like rye.  Really quite delicious as a session and every day beer.  6/4/8/4/17

Rerate.  Minnesota Winterfest 2012.  Dark brown color with a large head.  Dry chocolate aroma.  Light chocolate flavor.  Chalky mouthfeel.  Slightly acrid.6/4/6/3/14
On tap. A clear medium brown with smallish head. Aroma of caramel malt, maybe a little grain in there as well. Decent sweetness, slightly bland. Nothing special.

Had at G-nome. I got almost no aroma of anything. My pallate isnt as refind as most, but I found this to be very thin in the mouth, with a slight toffee taste that creeps in. Nothing offensive going on, but not much in the way of any malt/hop flavor. The most bland Surly beer to date, but since this is a Mild ale, I didnt expect to much. Very "sessionable" for sure. I dont have anything to compare this to, as I never have had a Mild before. Certainly will drink again. Good stuff if your in the session mood.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2008 Tap at the Happy Gnome.  Fairly clear body of damp red hue.  Weak and very sweet aroma of sugared red fruits and candies; with warmth a very earthy presence of pungent mulch, wild rice and wet grass begins to develop, eventually to fester into something rather unpleasant.  Flavors of chewy toffee and rock candy, of the type that ought to glaze the surface of a dense chocolate malt and belgian sugar body, sit restively without much substance beneath.  Hints of almond butter, lighter types of frosting, raspberry, and pear.  Light to medium bodied in the mouth, briskly carbonated and quite dry; hollows out with the drying, pasty kick of wheatgrass in the finish, leaving a very ambiguous impression.  It isnt exciting, nor is it especially sessionable to my taste given the extremes of sweetness and tea-leaf dryness that start and finish it.  Other examples of easygoing, flavorful beers fulfill this standard of substantive simplicity more amiably and with a lighter touch; it certainly isnt the fact that Surly chose to take a laid back route with this beer thats unsatisfying, its that their representation of this style isnt very accurate or compelling.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2017 Original rating, 1-16-08. Called "Surly Mild" at the time: Two pints on tap at the Happy Gnome in St. Paul during the official release on 1-16-08. Sweet, malty aroma features cherry, light chocolate, and apricot scents. The smell is weak but nice. Pours a hazy maroon with a bright amber hue and a small amount of beige head. Cool, intriguing appearance. Malty taste, but not nearly as sweet as the aroma suggests. The heart of the taste comes in the yeasty finish, which features bread, cardboard, sesame seed, and other spice flavors. Medium body (heavier than I expected). Smooth and crisp in the palate. Easy to drink and sessionable. If this werent called Surly Mild Ale, I would have considered it an amber, but a good one. This is about what I expected (and I had cautiously high expectations): Surly has taken a rather boring style and made it interesting and tasty. If the folks at Surly wanted to go the mainstream, accessible beer route (which they dont, thankfully), they could probably get this on tap all over Minnesota bars; Surly Mild Ale compares favorably to, say, Summit Extra Pale Ale. Is this a mind-blowing beer? No, but it is a damn fine effort for the style. 6/4/7/4/15=>3.6. Re-rate, 3-13-17. This time called "Surly Nitro Dodgy Geezer:" 8 oz. pour, on nitro tap at the brewerys taproom in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Consumed on 3-5-17. Pours a medium brown, almost maroon. Moderate to large amount of cream-colored head. Even head. Great color, great head, looks superb. Cant ask for more. Malty aroma. Chocolate covered pretzel scent. Simple smell, stronger than I expected. Certainly not bad but not a lot to the aroma. Strong pretzel flavor. Quite pleasant in taste. Nicely and heavily toasted malts. Good, toasted malt finish. A lot of flavor for the style. Light body. Aqueous. Insubstantial. Actually not awful palate effects by nitro standards but of course worse than carbonated beers. I quite enjoyed this. Really remarkably tasty (in strength and quality) for the style. 6/5/8/2/15=>3.6. Combined rating: 6/5/7/3/15=>3/6.

On draught at the Happy Gnome in St Paul,  Minnesota. Pours a clear reddish amber brew with a creamy off-white head that has excellent retention and thick/spotty lacing. Aroma of fruity caramel malt, a touch of tart pears, toffee and some citrus hops. Taste is smooth, medium bodied, very light carbonation with a fruity/caramel malty flavor. Finish is just as creamy and smooth as its taste along with a semi-dry finish, a light mild bitterness that quickly clean cuts to a crisp aftertaste. Another excellent brew by the Surly guys.
